references: Joy, J. B. 2000. Characteristics of nest cavities and nest trees of the Red-breasted Sapsucker in coastal montane forests. J. Field Ornithol. 71:525-530.
Grinnell, J. and A. H. Miller. 1944. The distribution of the birds of California. Pac. Coast Avifauna no. 27. Cooper Ornithol. Club, Berkeley, CA.
Devillers, P. 1970. Identification and distribution in California of the SPHYRAPICUS VARIUS group of sapsuckers. California Birds 1:47-76.

Campbell, R. W., N. K. Dawe, I. McTaggart-Cowan, J. M. Cooper, G. W. Kaiser, and M. C. E. McNall. 1990. The birds of British Columbia, Vol. 2: diurnal birds of prey through woodpeckers. R. Br. Columbia Mus. Victoria.
Gaines, D. 1977. Birds of the Yosemite Sierra. California Syllabus, Oakland. 153pp

Walters, Eric L., Edward H. Miller and Peter E. Lowther. 2002. Red-breasted Sapsucker (Sphyrapicus ruber), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/663a
Mannan, R. W. 1977. Use of snags by birds, Douglas fir region, western Oregon. Master's Thesis. Oregon State Univ. Corvallis, OR.
Lundquist, R. W. 1988. Habitat use by cavity-nesting birds in the southern Washington Cascades. Master's Thesis. Univ. of Washington, Seattle.
Nehls, H. 1985. Distribution of the Yellow-bellied type sapsuckers in Oregon. Oreg. Birds 11:155-158.
Bate, L. J. 1995. Monitoring woodpecker abundance and habitat in the central Oregon Cascades. Master's Thesis. Univ. of Idaho, Moscow, ID.
Raphael, M. G. 1980. Utilization of standing dead trees by breeding birds at Sagehen Creek, California. P.h.D. diss.,. Univ. of California, Berkeley, CA.
Garrett, K. and J. Dunn. 1981. Birds of southern California: status and distribution. Los Angeles Audubon Soc. Los Angeles, CA.
Mannan, R. W., E. C. Meslow, and H. M. Wight. 1980. Use of snags by birds in Douglas-fir forests, western Oregon. Journal of Wildlife Management 44:787-97.
Allaye-Chan, A. C. 1981. Snag use by cavity-nesting birds in the Chemainus Woodlands of southern Vancouver Island, British Columbia. B.S.F. thesis. Univ. of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC.
Kessel, B. 1986. Yellow-bellied Sapsucker, Sphyrapicus varius, in Alaska. J. Field Ornithol. 57:42-47.

Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.

Zimmerman, K. 1998. Sustaining biological diversity in managed sub-boreal spruce landscapes: residual habitat strategies for cavity nesting species. Master's Thesis. Univ. of Northern British Columbia, Prince George.
Winkler, H., D.A. Christie, and D. Nurney. 1995. Woodpeckers:a guide to the woodpeckers of the world. Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, Massachusetts.

Marcot, B. G. 1983. Snag use by birds in Douglas-fir clearcuts. Pages 134-139 in Snag habitat management: proceedings of the symposium. (Davis, J. W., Ed.) U.S. Dep. Agric., For. Serv., Rocky Mtn. For. Range Exper. Sta., Gen. Tech. Rep. RM-99, Fort Collins, CO.
McCaskie, G., P. De Benedictis, R. Erickson, and J. Morlan. 1988. Birds of northern California, an annotated field list. 2nd ed. Golden Gate Audubon Soc., Berkeley. Reprinted with suppl. 108pp.
Gilligan, J., D. Rogers, M. Smith, and A. Contreras. 1994. Birds of Oregon:Status and Distribution. Cinclus Publications, McMinnville, Oregon.
habitat_description:
Summer:
Breeds from near sea level to 2,900 m elevation in coniferous forests that include western white pine (Pinus monticola), lodgepole pine (P. contorta), western hemlock (Tsuga het-erophylla), Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), red fir (Abies magnifica), and spruce (Picea sp.); also in deciduous and riparian habitat including bottomlands of quaking aspen and cottonwood (Populus sp.); and in old-growth and second-growth forests of coast mountains. Also known to use orchards, power line rights-of-way, and burns in British Columbia (Campbell et al. 1990). More likely to breed in areas with snags (dead trees) than without (Marcot 1983).
In Alaska, breeds in spruce-hemlock coastal forests (Kessel 1986). In British Columbia, coastal populations nest in Douglas-fir-western hemlock-western white pine forests (Allaye-Chan 1981, Joy 2000); interior populations found in spruce forests (Zimmerman 1998). In sw. Washington, nests in Douglas-fir-western hemlock forests (Lundquist 1988). In Oregon, mainly in Douglas-fir-western hemlock forests and also nests on edges of 100–200+ yr-old Douglas-fir stands and old-growth near clearcuts (Mannan et al. 1980, Bate 1995); in sw. Oregon, primarily in riparian habitats (Mannan 1977). In n. California, nests in red fir-lodgepole pine-aspen forests (Raphael 1980)(quoted directly from Walters et al. 2002).
In California, this species is a fairly common year-round and summer resident of Coast Range mountain woodlands from the Oregon border to Marin County and the Sierra Nevada to Kern County. It breeds from sea level to about 2500 m. Preferred nesting habitat includes montane riparian forest, aspen, montane hardwood-conifer, and red fir adjacent to meadows, clearings, lakes and slow moving streams. During both winter and summer this species feeds over meadows, lakes and other open habitats. (Gaines and Granholm based on Zeiner et al. 1990).

Winter:
Winters from near sea level to 3,000 m (Winkler et al. 1995); individuals nesting in inland forests tend to move to more coastal habitat, often wintering in protected lowlands (Nehls 1985). In British Columbia, frequents deciduous and coniferous woodlands from open black cottonwood (Populus trichocarpa) bottomland, red alder (Alnus rubra) and maple (Acer sp.) regrowth, and riparian woods to dense, coastal Douglas-fir and western red cedar (Thuja plicata)-western hemlock forests (Campbell et al. 1990). In Oregon, often found at localities that do not support nesting (Gilligan et al. 1994)(quoted directly from Walters et al. 2002).
In California, the red-breasted sapsucker is a common resident of lowland and cismontane California from coastal areas and the Central Valley to Los Angeles County. It is an uncommon winter resident of the Channel Islands. Winter habitat includes deciduous woodlands, orchards, poplar, aspen, willlow, and birch forests (Grinnell and Miller 1944, Devillers 1970, Gaines 1977, Garrett and Dunn 1981, McCaskie et al. 1988)(quoted from Gaines and Granholm based on Zeiner et al. 1990).
